hints.content: Start by understanding the problem's requirements. You need to remove exactly n/2 elements from both nums1 and nums2, where n is the length of the arrays. This means you will always be left with n/2 elements in each array.

Consider how the elements in nums1 and nums2 can overlap. The maximum size of the set s will depend on how many unique elements you can keep after the removals. Think about how to maximize the number of unique elements in the final set.
Count the frequency of each element in both nums1 and nums2. This will help you understand which elements are most common and how many you can afford to remove while still keeping unique elements.

Remember that since you are removing n/2 elements from both arrays, you need to balance the removals. If you have many duplicates in one array, you might want to remove those to keep more unique elements.

Consider using sets to track unique elements. After counting frequencies, you can determine which elements to keep based on their counts in both arrays. This will help you maximize the size of the final set.
Think about edge cases, such as when all elements in nums1 are the same or when nums1 and nums2 have completely different elements. How would these cases affect the maximum size of the set?

As you plan your removals, keep in mind that you can only remove elements from nums1 and nums2 up to their counts. For example, if an element appears more than n/2 times in one array, you can only remove n/2 of them.

You might want to create a strategy to decide which elements to remove. A good approach could be to prioritize removing elements that are less frequent in both arrays, thus preserving more unique elements.
To implement your strategy, you can use a greedy approach. Start by trying to keep the most frequent elements from both arrays, while ensuring you are still removing the required number of elements.

Finally, after determining which elements to keep, compute the size of the set by combining the remaining elements from both arrays. Ensure that you account for duplicates correctly to get the final size.
